info.name: Destiny HTTP API
info.description:
This collection includes all the standard HTTP API requests available for the Destiny API.

Please see our Destiny API Quick Start Guide if you haven't yet.

request.description: Sends a notice email to support personel.

response.name: 200 OK

request.description: Sends a warning email to support.

response.name: 200 OK

request.description: Sends an email about an error to support.

response.name: 200 OK

request.description: Requests the data for a previously submitted user registration.

Performs a user login request. If successful an HTTP code `200 OK` will be returned together with a new authorization token. Look at the `Authorization` header in the response, it will contain something like `bearer eyJ0eXAiOiJKV1...`. 

> **Important:** This token must be cached by you and supplied with each subsequent requests to the API through the `Authorization` HTTP header.

> **Important:** The token is refreshed every few minutes by the API server. When any request is made by you and you receive the `Authorization` header, update your cache with the new token and then send the new token with each subsequent request. The old token does not immediately expire and is valid for 7 days.

response.name: 200 OK
425 User Not Found
401 Unauthorized

request.description: Log the user out.
Authenticates a logged-in user with the WebSentinel service.
Performs a password reset request for the given email address.
Performs a password reset based on the provided data.
Provide a previous registration token and the users data to complete the user's registration process.

Performs an organizational check for the logged in user. This includes a check whether a GET/POST/PUT/DELETE request can be performed on the supplied partner, agency or client. For convenience this request will return the user's primary details along with the user's permissions.

response.name: 200 OK

request.description: A request to see if the server responds to the requests.

item.name: Get Unit Comms Status Summary (Grouped by Client)

request.description: Returns the current status of all accessable units.

Requests a summary of unit communication status for a specific clients. The clients id's can be provided as comma separated values. The returned data contains the total number of units active, inactive, offline or that have never communicated to the server. The totals are updated every 10 minutes.

Requests a summary of unit communication status for a specific agencies. The agency id's can be provided as comma separated values. The returned data contains the total number of units active, inactive, offline or that have never communicated to the server. The totals are updated every 10 minutes.

Requests a summary of unit communication status for a specific partners. The partner id's can be provided as comma separated values. The returned data contains the total number of units active, inactive, offline or that have never communicated to the server. The totals are updated every 10 minutes.

Requests a summary of unit communication status for a specific partners. The partner id's can be provided as comma separated values. The returned data contains the total number of units active, inactive, offline or that have never communicated to the server. The totals are updated every 10 minutes.
This request add's an additional text note to the partner.

request.description:
Creates a safe-zone around a unit. The safe-zone will only be enabled once/if the unit is parked.

- Only one safe-zone can be created for a unit. Attempting to create another one will override the original safe-zone.
    
- The radius is in meters.
    
- The mode can be "private" or "monitored".
    
- In 'private' mode, one or more users of the Destiny mobile app can receive events and alarms for the safe-zone.
    
- In 'monitored' mode, both users and the control room may receive events caused by the safe-zone.

item.name: Get Vehicle Location Status by Client

request.description:
Returns the latest location status data for each vehicle under a specific client or clients.

Following are two examples for using this request:

1. Returns the location status data for all clients accessable to the user of the API: `/api/v1/vehicles/status/location/by-client/all`
2. Returns the location status data for the client id `555`. If the user of the API is a client level user, the id will be ignored and only accessable data will be returned: `/api/v1/vehicles/status/location/by-client/555`
    

_Note: If it seems that you are receiving duplicate records it is because a vehicle may be fitted with multiple GPS device/tracking units. In order to only see the data of the primary device (recommended as backup devices often have less data available) you can add the_ `?unit_assigned_as=primary` _filtering parameter, for example_:

```
/api/v1/vehicles/status/location/by-client/all?unit_assigned_as=primary

 ```

The request returns an array of objects having the following fields:

- `id (int)`: The vehicle's database id.
- `reg_no (string)`: Vehicle's registration number.
- `fleet_no (string|null)`: Vehicle's fleet number.
- `vehicle_make (string|null)`: Vehicle's make.
- `vehicle_model (string|null)`: Vehicle's model.
- `client_name (string)`: Client/customer name.
- `driver_name (string|null)`: Active or assigned Driver name.
- `vehicle_group_name (string|null)`: Vehicle's group name.
- `unit_assigned_as (string)`: Can be `primary`, `backup_1, backup_2.`
- `local_time (ISO 8601 date and time string|null)`: The local time of the GPS recording, local meaning the timezone where the GPS device finds itself in. It can be null if no GPS data has been captured by the device yet.
- `timezone (string)`: The configured/active timezone of the GPS device.
- `latitude (float)`: The decimal latitude in degrees.
- `longitude (float)`: The decimal longitude in degrees.
- `speed (int|float)`: The current GPS speed in km/h.
- `heading (int|float)`: The current GPS heading in degrees where 0 = North.
- `gps_fix (array of strings)`: Can be an empty array or have a combination of the following values: `"fixed", "predicted", "diff_corrected", "last_known", "2d", "logged", "invalid_time", "on_no_fix", "sleep"`. In most cases the array will be empty or only contain `"on_no_fix"` if there is no GPS fix.
- `odometer (int)`: Odometer in meters. This is currently only availble if the GPS device is configured to supply the odometer, returns 0 if no odometer is available.
- `address (int|null)`: Current address of the vehicle if available.
- `hours_behind (float)`: Can be used to determine how long ago the device transmitted a GPS location, the device's timezone is taken into account.
- `comms_status_code (string)`: Current communication status. Can be `"online", "inactive", "offline", "never"`.

item.name: Get Vehicle Trip Status by Client

request.description:
Returns the latest location and current trip status data (if trip in progress) for each vehicle under a specific client or clients.

Following are two examples for using this request:

1. Returns the location status data for all clients accessable to the user of the API: `/api/v1/vehicles/status/trip/by-client/all`
2. Returns the location status data for the client id `555`. If the user of the API is a client level user, the id will be ignored and only accessable data will be returned: `/api/v1/vehicles/status/trip/by-client/555`
    

_Note: If it seems that you are receiving duplicate records it is because a vehicle may be fitted with multiple GPS device/tracking units. In order to only see the data of the primary device (recommended as backup devices often have less data available) you can add the_ `?unit_assigned_as=primary` _filtering parameter, for example_:

```
/api/v1/vehicles/status/location/by-client/all?unit_assigned_as=primary

 ```

The request returns an array of objects having the following fields:

- `id (int)`: The vehicle's database id.
- `reg_no (string)`: Vehicle's registration number.
- `fleet_no (string|null)`: Vehicle's fleet number.
- `vehicle_make (string|null)`: Vehicle's make.
- `vehicle_model (string|null)`: Vehicle's model.
- `client_name (string)`: Client/customer name.
- `driver_name (string|null)`: Active or assigned Driver name.
- `vehicle_group_name (string|null)`: Vehicle's group name.
- `unit_assigned_as (string)`: Can be `primary`, `backup_1, backup_2.`
- `local_time (ISO 8601 date and time string|null)`: The local time of the GPS recording, local meaning the timezone where the GPS device finds itself in. It can be null if no GPS data has been captured by the device yet.
- `timezone (string)`: The configured/active timezone of the GPS device.
- `latitude (float)`: The decimal latitude in degrees.
- `longitude (float)`: The decimal longitude in degrees.
- `speed (int|float)`: The current GPS speed in km/h.
- `heading (int|float)`: The current GPS heading in degrees where 0 = North.
- `gps_fix (array of strings)`: Can be an empty array or have a combination of the following values: `"fixed", "predicted", "diff_corrected", "last_known", "2d", "logged", "invalid_time", "on_no_fix", "sleep"`. In most cases the array will be empty or only contain `"on_no_fix"` if there is no GPS fix.
- `odometer (int)`: Odometer in meters. This is currently only availble if the GPS device is configured to supply the odometer, returns 0 if no odometer is available.
- `address (int|null)`: Current address of the vehicle if available.
- `hours_behind (float)`: Can be used to determine how long ago the device transmitted a GPS location, the device's timezone is taken into account.
- `comms_status_code (string)`: Current communication status. Can be `"online", "inactive", "offline", "never"`.
- day_trip_no (int): The trip number of the day if a trip is active.
- active_trip (Object|null): The active trip data object if a trip is active, null if no trip is active.
    

The `active_trip` object contains the following fields and sub-fields:

- `avg_speed (float)`: The average speed of the active trip in km/h.
    
- `max_speed (float|int)`: The maximum speed in km/h reached during the active trip.
    
- `started_at (ISO 8601 date and time string|null)`: The local time when the GPS trip started.
    
- `distance_km (float)`: The distance travelled in the active trip.
    
- `start_address (string|null)`: The starting address of the active trip.
    
- `durations (Object)`: The various durations in "HH:MM:SS" recorded during the active trip.

request.description:
Creates a safe-zone around a vehicle. The safe-zone will only be enabled once/if the vehicle is parked.

- Only one safe-zone can be created for a vehicle/unit. Attempting to create another one will override the original safe-zone.
    
- The radius is in meters.
    
- The mode can be "private" or "monitored".
    
- In 'private' mode, one or more users of the Destiny mobile app can receive events and alarms for the safe-zone.
    
- In 'monitored' mode, both users and the control room may receive events caused by the safe-zone.

request.description:
Run a detailed debrief/trip report job on a specific vehicle and generate a PDF file.

**Important**: This starts a background job which will run asynchronously, and as such the results of the report is not returned immediately. Instead, the front-end can use an SSE connection to get feedback on the report or alternatively poll the report status using the `Get Report by Id` request.

Date range example 1:

```
"date_range_type": "day"
"date_range_day": "2023-12-06"

 ```

Date range example 2:

```
"date_range_type": "month"
"date_range_month": "2023-12"

 ```

Date range example 3:

```
"date_range_type": "date_range"
"date_range_from": "2023-12-01"
"date_range_to": "2023-12-06"

 ```

request.description:
Run a Vehicle Expenditure report job on the whole fleet of vehicles for a selected client and generate a PDF file.

**Important**: This starts a background job which will run asynchronously, and as such the results of the report is not returned immediately. Instead, the front-end can use an SSE connection to get feedback on the report or alternatively poll the report status using the `Get Report by Id` request.

Date range example 1:

```
"date_range_type": "day"
"date_range_day": "2023-12-06"

 ```

Date range example 2:

```
"date_range_type": "month"
"date_range_month": "2023-12"

 ```

Date range example 3:

```
"date_range_type": "date_range"
"date_range_from": "2023-12-01"
"date_range_to": "2023-12-06"

 ```

Group by examples:

```
"group_by": "vehicle_date" // Vehicle and invoice date
"group_by": "invoice_date" // Invoice date

 ```

Order By examples:

```
"order_by": "vehicle_reg_no"
"order_by": "vehicle_fleet_no"

 ```

PDF Option examples:

```
"pdf_options": "show_summary"
"pdf_options": "show_summary_only"
"pdf_options": "no_summary"

 ```

PDF Chart examples:

```
"pdf_charts": "show"
"pdf_charts": "dont_show"

 ```

Filters:

The `expense_category` filters array can be empty or any combination of these values: `"fuel", "general", "installments".`

The `expense_type` filter can be an empty array, and if not, contains an array of id's of the various expense types saved under the client.

The `tax_deductable` filter can either be empty, `"tax_deductable"` or `"not_tax_deductable"`.

item.name: Run Detailed Unit Operational Status PDF Report

request.description:
Run a Detailed Unit Operationl Status report job and generate a PDF file.

**Important**: This starts a background job which will run asynchronously, and as such the results of the report is not returned immediately. Instead, the front-end can use an SSE connection to get feedback on the report or alternatively poll the report status using the `Get Report by Id` request.

If no `partner_id`, `agency_id` or `client_id` is provided or these three fields are `null`, then the report will return with all the accessable units available to the user.

If only a `partner_id` is provided, then all the units of that partner is returned.

If an `agency_id` is provided and no `client_id`, then all the units of that agency will be returned.

If only a `client_id` is provided, then all the units of that client will be returned.

The `comms_status_code` filter can be any one or combination of the following:

```
"comms_status_code": ["active"]
"comms_status_code": ["inactive"]
"comms_status_code": ["offline"]
"comms_status_code": ["never"]

 ```

For example:

```
"comms_status_code": ["active", "offline"]

 ```

Please contact us for a list of `unit_type_code`, `unit_model_code` and `unit_status_code` codes:

Order By examples:

```
"order_by": "vehicle_reg_no"
"order_by": "partner_name,agency_name,client_name,!local_time"  // Client, GPS Timestamp
"order_by": "partner_name,agency_name,client_name,comms_status_code" // Client, Comms Status
"order_by": "!local_time" // GPS Timestamp (descending order)
"order_by": "comms_status_code" // Comms status code

 ```
